content.question: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A dart is launched horizontally from a platform at height <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>h</mi></math>. The dart hits the center of a target a horizontal distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math> away from the initial launch point, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. (a)i. The dart lands on the target at time <math alttext="t equals t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. On the following axes, sketch a graph of the vertical velocity <math alttext="v sub y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>y</mi></msub></math> and the horizontal velocity <math alttext="v sub x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>x</mi></msub></math> of the dart as a function of time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> from the time the dart leaves the platform until it hits the target. Take the upward direction as positive.

frqParts.text: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A dart is launched horizontally from a platform at height <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>h</mi></math>. The dart hits the center of a target a horizontal distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math> away from the initial launch point, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. (a)i. The dart lands on the target at time <math alttext="t equals t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. On the following axes, sketch a graph of the vertical velocity <math alttext="v sub y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>y</mi></msub></math> and the horizontal velocity <math alttext="v sub x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>x</mi></msub></math> of the dart as a function of time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> from the time the dart leaves the platform until it hits the target. Take the upward direction as positive.

ii. Starting with a kinematic relationship, derive an expression for the launch velocity <math alttext="v sub L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>L</mi></msub></mstyle></math> needed for the dart to hit the center of the target. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>h</mi></math>, <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

(b) The height of the platform is then increased, but the target is not moved. Indicate whether the launch velocity should be increased, decreased, or should remain constant for the dart to still hit the center of the target? Justify your claim.

skill.text: 1.C: Create qualitative sketches of graphs that represent features of a model or the behavior of a physical system.
